data.project_title: An ecosystem for community driven scanning probe microscopy research and development
data.project_abstract: Scientific instruments these days are often sophisticated, intelligent systems consisting of complex hardware, electronics, and software components. To innovate in the technique, one must get access to all levels; instrument, hardware, software. Unfortunately, most commercial instrument manufacturers keep their technology proprietary, and provide very little access to the hardware and software. Before one can improve things, one has to either hack into the commercial system, or completely re-engineer the instrument. In our research field (scanning probe microscopy) this has become painfully noticeable as a marked decrease in innovation. In this project we propose to bring together the community to share and standardise their hardware and software developments in the field of SPM. The goal is to reach an open development ecosystem in which new and existing research projects can be embedded without having to first reinvent the wheel. We plan to leverage our existing open hardware AFM projects and their early adopters to generate an OpenSPM ecosystem consisting of the Open Hardware tools (hardware and software), an extensive knowledge base and development resources, a world-wide user community, and a sourcing platform that helps people adopt the open hardware.

work_packages.wp_title: Establishing and improving the accessibility of the OpenSPM platform
Build an active user and developer community around our open platform
Interfacing and expanding to the broader SPM community

main_applicant_first_name.reasoning: There are two overlapping extractions: idx 0 (pages 0-7) gives 'Georg' as the main applicant's first name with verbatim extraction and maximal confidence. idx 1 (pages 7-10) only infers 'G.' from references. Since 'Georg' is the complete form and comes from a direct table listing of the first name, it is more accurate and preferred according to both the extraction strategy and index order.

project_title.reasoning: The formal project title, as per the extraction strategy, should be taken from the section explicitly labeled 'Project title' or its equivalent. This is found verbatim in the RESEARCH PROPOSAL table (idx:0, page 2), with a perfectly matching confidence score. Later references to 'OpenSPM ecosystem' are used as short-hand and do not supersede the formal title. Therefore, the most complete and formally-specified project title is returned.

work_packages.reasoning: Two tables present WP1: One as 'Establishing and improving OpenSPM platform' and the other with the more detailed 'Establishing and improving the accessibility of the OpenSPM platform'. The latter is more informative, so it is selected. Confidence is averaged between both sources.
Both titles cover similar themes, but the second includes user and developer detail, so it is preferred. Confidence for wp_identifier is the mean of both.
Both sources supply nearly identical phrasing. Selection is verbatim from the more detailed version. VERBATIM EXTRACTION.

config.system_prompt:
EXTRACTION STRATEGY:
  1. PRIMARY: Look for data in the specified location/table/section
  2. FALLBACK: If not found, search broader document context for semantically equivalent information
  3. FLEXIBILITY: Allow for format variations, OCR errors, and synonym usage

  LOCATION FLEXIBILITY:
  - Handle table format variations (column/row order, spacing, naming)
  - Consider synonyms and equivalent terms
  - Account for OCR/parsing errors that may affect document quality

  QUALITY STANDARDS:
  - Extract actual values found in the document
  - If uncertain, provide best interpretation with appropriate confidence
  - Only return null if the information category truly doesn't exist
  - Convert abbreviated amounts (k=1000) to full numbers where applicable
  

  METADATA EXTRACTION FOCUS:
  - Project identification: title, acronym, duration, start date
  - Applicant details: names, institutions, functions, addresses
  - Project categorization: Explore/Establish/Contribute classification
  - Keywords and abstract information from research proposal sections
